headline: PM Carney to meet with President Trump in Washington on Tuesday | CBC News
context: Prime Minister Mark Carney will meet with U.S. President Donald Trump in Washington on Tuesday to discuss trade and security.

annotations.paragraph: Darren Major  · CBC News
annotations.reason: This is an author credit and does not contribute to the article's core story.

annotations.paragraph: FULL SPEECH | Carney outlines his government’s priorities in 1st post-election news conference
annotations.reason: This is a headline for another piece of content and does not contribute to the article's core story.

annotations.paragraph: Prime Minister Mark Carney will meet with U.S. President Donald Trump in Washington on Tuesday to discuss trade and security.
annotations.reason: This paragraph directly states the main event of the article.

annotations.paragraph: Carney announced the trip during a news conference Friday morning, his first time taking questions from media since the Liberals won Monday's federal election.
annotations.reason: This provides context about the announcement and its timing, which is relevant to the article.

annotations.paragraph: "It's important to get engaged immediately, which has always been my intention, which has always been [Trump's] intention," he told reporters in Ottawa. "I'm pleased to have the opportunity for quite a comprehensive set of meetings that will take place on Tuesday."
annotations.reason: This quote from Carney provides direct commentary on the significance of the meeting.

annotations.paragraph: Carney made negotiations with Trump a cornerstone of his campaign, arguing he would be best to shepherd Canada through a trade war with the U.S. and Trump's annexationist threats. But the prime minister said Tuesday's meeting doesn't necessarily mean there will be an immediate resolution to the tariff issue.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on Carney's campaign focus and expectations for the meeting.

annotations.paragraph: WATCH | Carney doesn't expect a swift resolution with Trump:
annotations.reason: This is a prompt for a video, not a paragraph with information.

annotations.paragraph: Carney expects 'difficult discussions' with Trump
annotations.reason: This is a headline and does not provide new information.

annotations.paragraph: "Do not expect white smoke out of that meeting," Carney said jokingly, referring to the upcoming papal conclave.
annotations.reason: This quote adds a light-hearted comment but does not provide substantial information.

annotations.paragraph: While he indicated that the meeting itself was a good sign that things are moving in a positive direction, Carney repeated what he had said during the campaign: that the traditional relationship with the U.S. is "over" and that his government is looking for new trading relationships with other partners.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides insight into Carney's strategic direction and expectations from the meeting.

annotations.paragraph: Carney also emphasized that he's intent on building the Canadian economy to be less reliant on the U.S.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant context about Carney's economic strategy, which is pertinent to discussions with the U.S.

annotations.paragraph: "We have more than enough to do here at home…. We can have a bigger boost to our economy, to incomes, to jobs by focusing on building one Canadian economy, by building these nation-building projects, by focusing on getting productivity up, by reducing government waste, by driving investment in this country," he said.
annotations.reason: This quote elaborates on Carney's economic focus, which is relevant to the meeting's context.

annotations.paragraph: "We're going to focus on that while we have these negotiations with the Americans, and if the negotiations with the Americans take longer, so be it. We've got more than enough to do here."
annotations.reason: This quote highlights Carney's stance on negotiations with the U.S., directly related to the meeting.

annotations.paragraph: Carney laid out a number of his government's priorities going forward. He said his promised tax cut will be passed by Canada Day and will introduce measures he said would double the pace of housing construction.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides information on Carney's domestic policy priorities, which is relevant to his economic strategy.

annotations.paragraph: The Liberals won 168 seats in the federal election, not quite the 172 that are required for a majority in Parliament. The Conservative Party won 144 seats.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides election results, which are not directly relevant to the meeting with Trump.

annotations.paragraph: The prime minister acknowledged that voters are concerned about the cost of living and crime, key campaign issues that the Conservatives pushed. Carney said he had already spoken with opposition leaders and is committed to working with other parties.
annotations.reason: This paragraph does not relate to the meeting with President Trump and focuses on domestic political issues.

annotations.paragraph: Conservative Leader Pierre Poilievre didn't win his seat, giving rise to speculation that one of his MPs would step aside and allow him to run in a byelection.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is about internal Conservative Party politics and not related to the meeting with Trump.

annotations.paragraph: Alberta MP Damien Kurek announced Friday that he would be stepping aside to make room for Poilievre to run in his Battle River-Crowfoot riding.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is about a byelection in Canada and not related to the meeting with Trump.

annotations.paragraph: WATCH | Carney open to a quick byelection:
annotations.reason: This is a prompt for a video and does not provide information about the meeting with Trump.

annotations.paragraph: Carney says he'll trigger a byelection if Conservatives seek one for Poilievre
annotations.reason: This statement is about Canadian political processes and not related to the meeting with Trump.

annotations.paragraph: Prime ministers have control over the timing of byelections once a seat is vacated.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is unrelated to the meeting between Carney and Trump.

annotations.paragraph: Carney was asked if he would delay a byelection call to keep Poilievre out of the House for an extended period of time.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is unrelated to the meeting between Carney and Trump.

annotations.paragraph: "I've already indicated to Mr. Poilievre that if it's the decision of him and the Conservative Party to trigger … a byelection. I will ensure that it happens as soon as possible," Carney said.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is unrelated to the meeting between Carney and Trump.

annotations.paragraph: "No games. Nothing."
annotations.reason: This paragraph is unrelated to the meeting between Carney and Trump.

annotations.paragraph: Carney was also asked if he would be seeking a governing agreement with the NDP, similar to the one former prime minister Justin Trudeau had in the previous Parliament.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is unrelated to the meeting between Carney and Trump.

annotations.paragraph: "No," he said quickly in response.
annotations.reason: This is an isolated quote without context or relevance to the meeting with President Trump.

annotations.paragraph: When asked why not, he responded with a "why?" He expanded to say that his government, although a minority, was given a mandate by voters and will be putting forward legislation to move ahead with its agenda.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides information about Carney's government agenda, which is not directly related to the meeting with Trump.

annotations.paragraph: The prime minister said his new cabinet will be sworn during the week of May 12 and Parliament will return May 26.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides information about domestic political events unrelated to the meeting with Trump.

annotations.paragraph: Carney also said King Charles will travel to Ottawa to read the speech from the throne on May 27. The last time the speech was actually read by Canada's head of state was when Queen Elizabeth delivered it in 1977.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides historical context unrelated to the meeting with Trump.

annotations.paragraph: An original version of this story said that cabinet will be sworn in on May 12. In fact, cabinet will be sworn in the week of May 12.
annotations.reason: This is a correction note unrelated to the meeting with Trump.

annotations.paragraph: May 02, 2025 3:38 PM EDT
annotations.reason: This is a timestamp and does not contribute to the article's core story.

annotations.paragraph: Darren Major is a senior writer for CBC's Parliamentary Bureau. He can be reached via email at darren.major@cbc.ca.
annotations.reason: This is author information and does not contribute to the article's core story.
